I was never an active smoker, but I remember since age 16 or so I've been interested in cigarettes because the smell of some of the brands appealed to me.
I tried my first cigarette at 16, never actively smoked, but I did smoke an occasional cigarette or two when going out (less than 5 cigarettes in one year). I never got addicted though because I never properly inhaled it or felt its effects. Inhaling into the lungs made me nauseous.

In 2021 I was severely stressed out and despite never being addicted to smoking, I had a huge need for a cigarette and bought myself a pack... I smoked maybe 2 cigarettes out of the entire pack because it didn't appeal to me as much, but when I was on holiday with my friend, severely stressed out because I had a breakup at that time, I smoked up to 2-3 cigarettes in a row, which never happened before.

After that, I didn't smoke nor did I have the need to. I was looking into vapes much later in the year, and got my first disposable vape pen then. Boy did that hit so much different than the cigarette! Not only did it feel better than a cigarette, it also tasted delicious! I literally can't stand cigarettes anymore after vaping for a few months, but the issue I have now is being sorta addicted to vaping. I'm trying to keep it under control so I don't vape often, maybe once a month, simply because I don't trust these liquids enough...

What no one ever talks about when referencing long term effects of vaping is that you can get ZERO nicotine vape juice. That's what vaping initially started for. It was started as a way to ween off of cigarettes/nicotine completely. You start at a comfortable nicotine level and gradually decrease your nicotine levels in your vape until you reach zero nicotine. That's what VAPE SHOPS are for because you can customize your nicotine levels there and most vape shops keep tabs on any found harmful chemicals as to take them out of use of their vape juices. The vape shop taking care not to use harmful chemicals plus getting to zero nicotine greatly reduces many health issues with vaping.  The biggest issue is people not being educated about this stuff. The worst of all vape products is the random brands you get for gas stations, convenient stores, grocery stores, etc. They could care less what's in their product. Invest the money into a proper pen vape or box mod, learn to maintain it properly and only use custom vape juice from a vape shop you trust.

I started smoking in 2020 thinking it would help me combat my stressful life. It did not go well. I was burning through a pack of dunhill menthols every two days. Couple months later, I bought a vape and some 50mg nicotine ejuice. Every month I bought a juice with a lower nicotine level. Right now I'm using 6mg and by the end of this year I'll be nicotine free. What people fail to realise about vaping is that it's a tool, not a toy. Vaping was originally designed as an alternative to smoking but eventually people saw it as a way to quit smoking for good. Mainly because with vaping, people have direct control over how much nicotine they put in their vaporisers. Hence, it smoothes the quitting process to the point it just feels like drinking a glass of lemonade or chewing some gum. I personally love fruit and menthol flavors because it tastes better obviously and the added benefit is that it dissociates the nicotine high from cigarette smoke taste. I've been smoke free for well over a year thanks to vaping and in the next couple of months I will be nicotine free. I hope my story has inspired those reading it. If you smoke, stop right away or start vaping and stop eventually. If you've never smoked, don't bother to vape because honestly it can get quite expensive.

From my personal experience:

I was smoking for about three years (at age of 18), then i switched to e-cig. After a year and a bit of vaping I started to feel pain in my chest around heart. Eventually my heart got so sore I had to call ambulance where they noticed that my heartrate is at around 150-160 without doing anything. After week and a half of test (even angiography) six of my doctors didn't find a single thing that could be wrong. At the hospital my heart was occasionally sore. When I got home first thing i did was grabbing a vape and take some puffs... After couple minutes my heart got sore again. I switched back to ciggarettes and my heart is not sore for years.

Conclusions:
Don't get addicted to nicotine or quit immediately.

Secondhand affects should be everyone’s top priority.

I personally have extremely sensitive lungs, For no real reason. I have been tested for asthma two separate times but both tests came back clear.
Despite the tests, Any air pollutant causes me coughing and requires me to work extra hard to pull air into my lungs.

In order from Worst Irritant to least:

1. Diesel Exhaust
2. Cigarette Smoke
3. Gasoline Exhaust
4. Vape Smoke
5. Any Strong Smell (Not even exaggerating)
(Honorable mention-Alcohol )
My whole life, Family has smoked inside during family gathering, sometimes even in the same roommate me and Smoked in the car with me with only 1 window slightly cracked. It wasn’t until I was at least 11-12 that my mother finally managed to quit smoking, Partly due to its effect on me.

Now that Vapeing became a thing, they have all traded their cigarettes for Vapes, Which at the very least means i can breathe slightly better, but they still continue to vape with me in close proximity. Both I and my mom as well have repeatedly explained and requested they pull over to vape or step outside of the house to vape while i’m there, But they don’t seem to care.

Probably the most irritating part of it is that a few people in my family who didn’t smoke before, started Vaping. Just for gods sake people, If somebody in your family is sensitive, Make an effort at the very least to not use around them! It’s really not that difficult. People like me shouldn’t have to choose between spending time with family and being able to comfortably breathe.

I've always felt like AsapScience has a balanced, pragmatic view of drugs, but here I feel they fall short.
True, there are no longitudinal studies, but there are so few compounds in the vapor that it's not that much of a gamble. We know nicotine itself isn't particularly cancer-causing, and the PG and VG bases are no new mystery compounds.
True, more young people might start vaping than would have started smoking, but how many? An increase from 6 to 20% is just not nearly enough to offset the public health benefits of recommending that everyone switch away from combustion. It looks like the sum total of the negative effects of vaping is extremely unlikely to surpass 10% of that of smoking, so even if 10 times more people start vaping than would have smoked it should still be worth promoting vaping with all your heart!
Of course that won't be the case, so vaping comes out even further on top.

It’s kinda scary to think about. There’s been so many times where something dangerous became a trend and they didn’t know until later. Like tanning butter, glow in the dark paint, cigarettes, and possibly vape. Something people don’t talk about often is the DDT epidemic that took place decades ago in the United States. It was the first main pesticide and before Americans knew it wasn’t fit for human inhalation, it was spraying in masses. They resulted in the decrease in population of many different species. Bald eagles were put on the endangered list because the DDT caused the female eagles to somehow lay eggs with abnormally thin egg shells. So when the female bird would sit on the eggs, they would crack. It’s not something people talk about but should be taught in high school science. If vape is similar to DDT then I worry for what unknown effects it may cause on our generations to come.

Cigarettes and marijuana and have been used for centuries, but only recently has the process of vaporizing these substances become popular. So what does science have to say about this technology? Is vaping actually good for you?

When smoking normally, the heat from fire causes substances to change from a solid state to a vapor. In cigarettes, this releases nicotine which is absorbed into your bloodstream through the lungs, causing increased heart rate, constricted blood vessels, a release of dopamine in the brain, and feelings of alertness. But because nicotine is a stimulant, once it’s no longer present, you crash and crave more, which ultimately leads to addiction in many people. In the case of marijuana, the active component Tetrahydrocannabinol (aka THC) is aerosolized and follows the same pathway into your body, but with different effects.

Smoking only takes six seconds for the active compounds to reach your nervous system. This smoke consist of partially burned particles, which creates tar in your body, has cancer causing effects, blackens teeth and destroys taste buds. This is where vaping comes in. If you can heat the active components enough to become aerosolized without starting a combustion reaction with the other compounds, then you theoretically get fast effects without the damage of smoke inhalation.

Vaping typically involves a glass or metal chamber which has an electrical current passing through it. This way, it can be heated to a controlled temperature, creating a vapor with minimal combustion, meaning you inhale much less smoke. For marijuana users, vaporizers have become popular as the plant material can be heated to a specific temperature — usually between 185 and 210 degrees Celsius — allowing just the THC containing vapor to be extracted. For e-cigarettes, using a liquid solution instead of dried tobacco, has become popular; this e-liquid contains water, nicotine, a base and occasionally flavourings, and vaporizes at a much lower temperature. But this is where things get tricky.

The “e-liquid” contains a base similar to that used in cosmetics and food which helps maintain moisture without creating sogginess. One common base called propylene glycol, which is also used in theatrical smoke, is known to cause irritation to the eyes and respiratory infections.

SO WHAT HAPPENS AFTER PROLONGED USE OF E-CIGARETTES?
Scientists are still studying these effects, and even though in America the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has given the seal of approval, much is still unknown.

E-liquid can also differ greatly between manufacturers with barely any regulation for additives. Some have been found to contain diacetyl, a chemical that is known to give butter its “buttery” taste. Inhalation of this chemical can lead to scarring in the lungs known as “popcorn lung,” named after hundreds of workers who inhaled the chemical in a microwaveable popcorn factory and suffered irreversible lung damage. This is an example of how the lack of quality control in e-cigarettes should be a significant concern.

But, current evidence does indicate that vaporizers administer nicotine with far less adverse effects due to decreased carcinogenic products and smoke inhalation. But less harmful does not mean safe. E-cigarettes with added flavouring (such as blueberry or grape) have been found to contain other harmful chemicals.

IS SECOND-HAND SMOKE STILL AN ISSUE WITH E-CIGARETTES?
The answer is yes. Exhaled particles from vaporizers known as “ultra-fine particles” are known to affect pulmonary health. Others are worried that because these “e-cigs” are deemed healthier that they are becoming more appealing for young people. A study reported that continued use of e-cigarettes for teens in grades 6 to 12 had increased from 6% to 20% over three years.

On the other hand, much of the information we have on the adverse effects of smoking comes from long-term studies, with cancers appearing much later life. Since vaporizer use is relatively new we simply don’t have the same access to longitudinal studies. So we’ll wait to see!

Those studies didn't actually show a link between diacetyl and popcorn lung, nor has there been any reported cases of popcorn lung being developed due to vaping. That's the same ingredient the CNN uses to fearmonger, and they cite debunked sources where vaping was done improperly. Some juices are designed for low wattage vaping, they may be harmful if vaped in high wattage devices due to the concentration of certain additives, and this is well known, they disregard this, and worse they were running coil heads way beyond their maximum rated wattage which results in combustion of the liquid and of the wicking material, as well as damage to the coil itself which is where you get all of those other harmful things that don't show up in normal use, like aldehydes, metals, etc. These things shouldn't be presented without disclaimers that these studies are highly controversial.

While usually these are spot on, you are actually false in some of your research. When vape juice is created no water is added at all and its actually reccomended by companies that if you make your own juice that you do so in a moisture controled environment to keep from having water in the juice as it can cause pneumonia. Also Dyacydl has been banned from being used in vape juice by the FDA itself to prevent popcorn lung. While it is true we dont know for sure the long term effects, vaping is actually shown to also decrease the amount of tar in your lungs from smoking by using 2 of the main 3 components of the juice (Propoline Glycol and Vegetable Glycerin) to break up the tar enough so that the body can dispose of it naturally to the best of its ability. Vaping may not be for everyone and it may not be as healthy as some make it out to be, however according to a UK study it is actually approximately 99% better for you than smoking cigarettes. However more research is needed in order to confirm this statement and that can only come from long term research

Funny how all these pseudo anti-vape videos love to mention diacetyl, when in fact the average amount of diacetyl ingested during vaping is 750 times LOWER than what you would get from a CIGARETTE.

http://tobaccoanalysis.blogspot.com/2015/12/new-study-finds-that-average-diacetyl.html

No, vaping is not "good for you," but it is, unquestionably, substantially safer than smoking. This has been demonstrated again and again by all notable metrics, and was recently confirmed via meta analysis:

https://www.forbes.com/sites/jacobsullum/2016/04/28/royal-college-of-physicians-says-e-cigarettes-can-prevent-almost-all-the-harm-from-smoking/#1fbdc36d49b8

All videos like this do are convince smokers that vaping isn't worth it, so they continue smoking. I'm addiction therapist who concurrently runs a smoking cessation group, and I see it all the time. Nicotine addiction is one of the most powerful addictions known to neuroscience, and there are millions of people out there who simply cannot quit at this point in their lives. The benefits of them switching to vaping would be immense, but many do not because they believe the myth that vaping is just as harmful if not worse than smoking. Harm reduction is vital in saving lives when it comes to addiction. Videos like this are NOT helping, and those posting them should be ashamed of themselves.

I smoked for 3 years, roughly 2 and sometimes 2 and a half packs a day. I felt horrible. I'd developed a constant cough, got sick constantly, physically could not take deep breaths, always snotty, always spitting, horrible circulation, smelled horrible, offended people, had to hide or find a far away place to light up. Been vaping for roughly a year now and almost all of the adverse affects of smoking have completely vanished. I remember shortly after transitioning I developed this horrible cough (this is common) and my body cleared itself of about 2 liters of brown sludge from my time smoking. It's like I'm able to breathe again (not to mention I'm saving roughly $6,000 a year). Do REAL research. Smoking corporations like Marlboro have an incredibly vested interested in condemning vaping and scaring people away from it. Numerous studies advertising the harmful effects of vaping have been found to be fake or completed under super suspicious circumstances (for example the 'popcorn lung' myth condemns e liquid for using a substance that is at least 100X more active in cigarettes and to this day rarely actually seen in recent liquid brands). Scientists can be bought- so can the media. Don't trust every single article you read and look for trustworthy sources before making a decision either way.

I was a smoker for about a year when I decided to quit cold turkey. The withdrawal was rough, but after about a month or so I felt pretty comfortable as a non-smoker. About 2 months ago, I relapsed due to stress, and decided to switch to a vapor device since it seemed “less dangerous” than actual cigarettes. However, I found I was using the device MUCH more frequently than when I used to smoke, and since there is substantially more nicotine in vapor juice than in cigarettes, I needed a much larger amount of nicotine to get buzzed. I also started to notice that I had increased heart rate, constricted breathing, and other adverse side-effects from vaping. So I decided to quit cold turkey again, and that was SIGNIFICANTLY worse than the first time. My physical dependency on nicotine was much higher than before, and I had an episode where my heart was beating so fast/hard that I thought I was having a heart attack (I’m only 19 years old). Long story short, e-cigs are much more dangerous than actual cigs because they’re more convenient, more addictive, and seemingly “safe.” It’s sad to me to see teenagers getting into this stuff, because I know they’re heading down the exact same path I did. I can tell you from first-hand experience, e-cigs are NOT safer than cigarettes, and any smart person should know not to mess with them.

What the hell guys.. seriously revisit this one please. Holy dooley this is bad. I know it was made in 2015 but still. Okay so Popcorn Lung is baloney. That chemical is found in levels HUNDREDS! of times higher in cigarettes, yet not a single case of "popcorn lung" has been found in any smoker, ever. So obviously it's not an issue. That has been LONG debunked.
Plus, most companies got rid of that aditive instantly, not that it was a health concern either way.. just a business decision. That chemical is only found in the buttery sort of flavours too (makes sense), but there's other additives that can be used instead.. they just aren't as good.

All the flavourings are food grade and likely fine. But more research is always welcome in this area. It is "harm reduction" though, not that there's much harm at all.

Next was secondhand vapour.. studies have shown that no harmful chemicals are detected in the air even when they're measuring an actual vape cloud. Not even nicotine was picked up in a vape shop setting with visible clouds (not that everyone uses nicotine). To pick up nicotine you need a veryyy small room!

Another study just recently released in Australia showed long term effects of vaping every day all day with nicotine, where they followed vapers for 3.5 years, and found NO negative health effects at all.

Now some people can be allergic to some of the base ingredients, and PG isn't recommended for pregnant women, so keep that in mind.

I dunno what that school statistic was.. but in the UK, the number of teens who are picking up vaping not because they are quiting cigarettes, scientists said is so miniscule that it's statistically too difficult to even track.
AND, who cares anyway. Eating a cupcake with sugar in it is FAR worse, look at the evidence and update this video please.

Also nicotine is blown out of the water.. the other chemicals in cigarettes are far more difficult to quit than nicotine. Nicotine is more on par with caffeine in reality, as far as health effects as far as I'm aware. Vapers don't find it that difficult to cut down either.. they all do it.

This video was really bad... very damaging, and it's just keeping people on the cigarettes. I know it's old, but it's definitely time for an update.

Diacetyl huh? Causes "popcorn lung" huh? Fact. Traditional cigarettes contain more diacetyl than the maximum amount of diacetyl permitted in e-juices. A lot more. Yet there is no connection between smoking and "popcorn lung". The only documented cases are of factory workers who were exposed in higher amounts. Also since the diacetyl scare, most e-juice companies have eliminated it from their products and even before that, not all e-juice companies used it in the first place, and it was only found in certain flavors of others. E-cigs have the potential to get people off of smoking cigarettes, which are more harmful according to every scientific study I've came across. If you can't quit, you should not be scared out of choosing a far less harmful source of nicotine.

Just a small complaint: you're saying propylene glycol is 'known to cause irritation and infection of lungs'. I just checked your sources (and their sources), and they refer not to a published paper, but to a safety sheet about propylene glycol. So I checked several (7) of these safety sheets and... you got the only safety sheet mentioning possible infection, the others either state there is 'low effect' on the lungs on inhalation, even on long-term exposure (2), or just mention that the substance could cause temporary irritations of the respiratory tract (4). Also would appreciate if you used actual scientific papers that have been peer-reviewed. If I sell stuff and don't know much about it (and am too lazy to read into), I'm much more likely to just write that it COULD cause all sorts of stuff. These safety sheets are not peer-reviewed, and don't have to be based on studies and follow a 'better safe than sorry' policy.
Also: so you found a manufacturer that puts diacetyl in their vape-juice... was the dose high enough to cause lung-damage? How many manufacturers did this? I couldn't find your source for this, only found an article on 'http://www.ecigarette-research.org' stating that their diacetyl study is sometimes used in the wrong way: failing to mention the low doses in e-cigs and failing to mention that normal cigarettes contain FAR more diacetyl (100 times more), when smoked.

Coming from someone who's met many people in the e-liquid industry, and made my own e-liquid, I can tell you exactly how dated this video really feels. In e-liquid, you essentially have only a few ingredients like they said in the video. You have your nicotine in various strengths, your flavoring (which is quite literally the exact same kind of artificial flavoring they use to make candy), often water, and your base. Your base is made up of a combination of vegetable glycerin and propylene glycol (which are again both typically used in food production). The video states that diacetyl is often used in the base, but that's pretty far from the truth. It's long been known by the industry and consumers alike that diacetyl is incredibly harmful when inhaled, so no e-liquid manufacturer in their right mind actually still puts it in their product. The only time you really run the risk of finding harmful chemicals like that in your liquid is going to be in the extremely low quality liquids you find at gas stations or flea markets. If you buy liquid manufactured by a reputable company at a vape shop I can promise that won't be an issue. If you don't believe me then check the labels on the e-liquid you see there. The FDA legally requires manufacturers to list what's in every bottle sold commercially across the United States. If you're worried about propylene glycol inhalation there are many many liquids out there that use 100% vegetable glycerin as a base, which hasn't shown to be harmful when inhaled. Of course, vaping is still a fairly new idea and we have much less data on the longterm effects of using e-cigarettes compared to conventional ways of smoking. That being said though, all signs still point to vaping being a much, much safer way to consume nicotine than to smoke cigarettes, and studies have been able to prove that e-cigarettes are the most effective way to quit consuming nicotine altogether.

Sorry for the long post, but I imagine many people out there are watching this video because they're thinking about getting away from cigarettes, and I can see how the information presented here might be misunderstood and make some people feel like vaping really isn't much less dangerous than smoking.

comment_text: Too bad that i inhale water vapor instead of drugs.

So much of the info in this video is incorrect. It's not nicotine that harms your body, it's the smoke and other chemicals in the cigarette. It's called smoking bc you are inhaling smoke, not vapor. And there is NO TOBACCO in personal vaporizers. You are not heating tobacco leaves. That'd be smoking. You heat a liquid, turning it into a vapor, which you then inhale. Unlike smoking, there's not hundreds of harsh chemicals that build a layer of tar in your lungs that harm and destroy your body. Vaping is about the same as boiling water. There's as little as 1 and as many as 4 ingredients in vape liquid: Vegetable glycerin (VG), propylene glycol (PG), flavoring, and nicotine. Vegetable glycerin can be used by itself bc it's naturally sweet and it's what produces the vapor. Propylene glycol is used in many foods to enhance flavor. It's used for the same reason in a lot of vape liquids. To enhance the flavor and bond it to the vegetable glycerin. The flavoring is to make it taste even better than just straight VG does. And the nicotine is in some liquids, but not all. It's there to help smokers quit. Smokers switching to vaping can use a higher nicotine level and decrease it over time until they have 0 nicotine in the liquid. And then they can quit vaping if they want. Or they can continue to vape bc they enjoy blowing huge clouds of vapor. My point in saying all this, before you go and make a video on something you know nothing about. Take some time to research FACTS and not what the news or somebody else that knows nothing about vaping is saying. Next time, talk to some folks that use a vape and see what they know.

I think vaping is, initially, a great way to quit smoking. The problem is that too many people fall in to the vape trap and then end up relapsing. You usually start with an ego or a cig a like in a tobacco flavor with high nic. But for most people, you don't stay there long. Gradually you move towards higher powered, more complicated devices, and in the process you lower your nic levels significantly. The problem is that as your devices and flavors become more and more complicated, you begin to move further and further away from what helped you quit and substitute in the first place. Eventually you begin to crave the simplicity of cigarettes. Ironically you had the simplistic design very early on, but now that you've gone through so many different devices and tons of money, you decide it's easier to just start smoking again. And you do. This is the vape trap. All those fancy sub ohm devices might look really cool, but if you use vaping as a cigarette substitute, beware of needless or premature upgrades that will eventually leave you wanting and bring you back full circle

"In itself, abstaining from tobacco smoking by switching to ECs is likely to lower the risk of respiratory infections and pneumonia. Also, given that propylene glycol in its aerosol form is a potent bactericidal agent "

Well here it says PG is a potent killer of bacteria and that is going to drastically lower risks of lung infections since it kills bacteria.

https://pneumonia.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s41479-016-0001-2

"Only one study (to date) models the interaction between EC aerosol emissions and susceptibility to airway infection. Sussan et al. [21] exposed mice to EC vapour for 2 weeks, followed by pneumococcal infection. EC-exposed animals had increased pneumococcal colony forming unit counts in both the airway and lung tissue. There are several problems with the design of the study and the authors’ interpretation of the results. The mice in the experimental group were exposed to a much higher level of stress than the control group, and stress affects bacterial and viral response. Moreover, the experimental conditions exposed the animals to significant nicotine poisoning, with an average cotinine concentration of 267 ng/ml. Cotinine is the primary metabolite of nicotine and in humans the amount of nicotine needed to give similar cotinine levels are tolerated by heavy smokers, but highly aversive to non-smokers, who would be expected to feel sick and vomit at this level of exposure. Mice are much more sensitive to nicotine than humans (lethal dose in mice is 3 mg/kg, in humans it is 6.5–13 mg/kg) [22]. The observed accelerated weight loss, reduced immunity and early death in the experimental group were more likely the result of protracted stress and nicotine poisoning.

These interesting findings in rodents do not corroborate the evidence in humans. Despite millions of regular EC users, there has been no evidence of new emerging pneumonia outbreaks in recent years, or reports of infectious pneumonia in the medical literature. However, we are aware of a case of lipoid pneumonia that respiratory physicians in the United States have suggested being a direct consequence of vaping [23]. Lipoid pneumonia is a rare respiratory illness that may occur from aspiration or inhalation of fatlike material in the lung; an occurrence that is commonly reported in elderly people after accidental ingestion of oil-based laxatives. The assertion that vaping could put people at risk of lipoid pneumonia is illogical, simply because commercially available e-liquids do not contain nor generate fatlike material. A more plausible cause for this patient’s lipoid pneumonia was the acute exposure to fumigation chemicals, which may contain crude essential oils."

comment_text: This video was like 2 years ago, I'm sure less of the "problems" with E-Cigs are fixed now.

the whole popcorn lung thing is a bit exaggerated.
diacetyl is found in very low concentrations in E-liquids that have a slightly buttery flavor.

the guys who got popcorn lung were spending 8-12 hours a day, every day, breathing in vaporised butter flavoring.
not butter flavoured liquid... actual butter flavouring in it's most concentrated form.

arguing the diacetyl point is like saying that you should not drink tap water because it contains chlorine, a chemical which could kill you... in exponentially higher concentrations and exposure times...

not to mention that you can just buy juice without diacetyl, if it's really a deal breaker for you.
MOST e-juice contains no diacetyl at all, and you can safely avoid it by avoiding creamy/buttery flavors

In the end, is vaping better for your health? If the alternative is smoking cigarettes, it appears that the immediate answer is yes, although this is a slippery slope given that this assumption then leads to another assumption that they are 'healthy'. I understand that smoking cigarettes is actually a combustion process that allows unburned particles to accumulate in the lungs, and as the video informs, it allows the buildup of tar as well. This has been shown to be detrimental to pulmonary health in numerous of studies over the past 35 years. We now as a society know that smoking cigarettes is bad for your health. Period. As for vaping, time and time again I hear that "all I'm exhaling is water vapor" except that is not the case, it has never been the case, the vapor contains many ultra-fine particles as several studies have shown. Also, water vapor doesn't have a scent. Either way, the real concern for me is that longitudinal studies cannot occur until vaping products have been around for a longer period of time, and if this craze is starting with children who are 12 and continuing on into late adulthood, by the time we have real long term data, the damage will be done. As a general rule, inhaling hot, or burning, or vaporized anything is not a good idea. And for that reason, one would assume that the FDA would place more restrictions on both manufacturing of liquids, and the age in which purchasing is allowed. Until they do, vaping will continue to be self-regulated and with that, possibly even more harmful to health. Regardless of whether you are for or against vaping, the long-term effects have not had a chance to be studied yet, and the overall future outlook is eerily similar to that of cigarettes 75 years ago.

So, I know it's anecdotal, but you claim in the video here that Propylene Glycol can cause lung infections. You see, I used to get lung infections about once a year. Bronchitis, mainly. I smoked. Even when I was suck with a lung infection, I smoked.

Then I switched to vaping. I haven't had a lung infection a single time in the 3 years since I started. Like I said, that's just my experience, but the claim that vaping can cause lung infections, in my case, is not true at all. It saved me from them, in comparison to when I was smoking cigarettes.

Also, the "Popcorn Lung" incident happened only once, at a plant with poor safety standards. This plant processed a lot of chemicals in addition to Diacetyl. There is no proof that this chemical is the one which caused the condition, when there were thousands of other chemicals in the air at that plant, many of them toxic. Some of those toxic chemicals are the precursors to Diacetyl, which is actually a safe enough molecule that it is known by another name: Butter Flavoring. That's right. You eat that shit every day.

UPDATE: It is now illegal for vape shop owners to compare cigarettes to vapes, to let you taste the flavor before buying, or for the vape shop owner to even touch your vape device. They can still charge your batteries for you, if you happen to have 3 hours to wait.

I personally don't trust E-cigs at all, however I do use them to help me quit cigarettes, the only problem is you find yourself getting addicted to them.  I've quit cigarettes for a couple years now but when times get hard, they become my vice :(, so I try to opt for e-cigs because even though their addictive, they are not as addictive as cigarettes are for me (which I will chain smoke regardless of how long I've quit for). I've noticed e-cigs make me feel really dehydrated, makes my skins/hair dry & not glowing & make my cardio (breathing) a lot worse, & give me chest pain, which makes me wonder, Whats is it doing behind the scenes. So I avoid buying the liquid, etc. ones you can refill, & instead buy the disposable so that I don't keep having it (because I will keep smoking it)plus there more expensive, which will make you wna stop buying them :). When you do wna quit, do it when people who can irritate you are not around you, when your least stressed, take naps, drink grapefruit juice, eat frozen grapes, get beautiful smelling candles (and close your eyes & smell them when there not lite,lol, the deep breathing really helps), drink lots of water, & expect body withdrawals (bloating, acne, irritability, fatigue) which will go away shortly after a few days. Leaving you Happy, Glowing, & Healthy, and if your a female, do Do-It-Yourself spa/pampering days for yourself (face-masks, deep hair conditioning, nails polish, exfoliate, etc.) to make you feel beautiful, & relaxed.Also you may want to avoid coffee & alcohol, as that make you feen for cigs more. Just make sure you find something to go to, or do, when your stressed, mad, bored, etc. so you don't fall back in. Also 1800-No-Butts helps, they'll talk to you (like a therapist for free) so you can deal with your problems instead of running to nicotine for an escape. Remember the struggle is real, and when you fall back in, you can get out even better & more knowledgeable of why you went back in. Oh & last but not least Reward Yourself!!! You Deserve it :)!!!

Many common mistakes (or confidence in propaganda disguised as science) in this video :
- propylene glycol is not an irritant in those quantities, it doesn't cause infection (in fact it kills some bacteria)
- diacetyl is also found in tobacco cigarettes (those "approved by FDA") but in 10x-1000x higher quantities than when found in eLiquid
- tobacco has been known to be dangerous for decades before long longitudinal studies, the CO in smoke alone was known to be toxic before the 20th century. Cancers (in general) were less well known before the 60's which explains the long studies at the time
- nicotine alone is not the cause of addiction, it is only known to be addictive in tobacco (because of other components reinforcement and of the harm tobacco combustion causes). With no harm there is no addiction.
- vaping has been demonstrated safe for bystanders for years. And ultrafine particules in the vapor are liquid, those dangerous are solid (in smoke from cigarettes, cars, etc.)

Here's something the video doesn't really mention that's pretty important I feel. Data on people who managed to stop smoking in the UK for one year shows that only 3 per cent to around 5 per cent do it. This rises a few per cent if they use stop smoking aids like patches. Pretty miserable statistic as this data only covers people who really want to stop smoking.

Now the data on people who switch from smoking to vaping, the success rate rises to around 30% and that continues to rise every year as vaping products improve and become easier to get hold of.

People who vape don't die of lung cancer or suffer debilitating diseases and health problems. There is some tiny risk involved and sure that risk is enough to warn new users away. Vaping is not something you should consider if you don't smoke.

Also nicotine itself gets a bad rap. Yes its highly addictive but actually pretty harmless stuff unless you manage to take a massive overdose by drinking it or something stupid. Vaping nicotine has almost no health risks associated with it at all.

So to smokers I'd say, get on the vaping! Your health will improve and then you can consider later on stopping vaping by reducing the nicotine slowly over time but you shouldn't underestimate the addictive kick nicotine has. It's a tough one to give up and most people never manage it but at least vaping is fairly cheap, not much risk to your health and is quite a pleasant experience with the right equipment.

Incorrect facts about (1) the bodily effects of nicotine and (2) the negative effects of PG (propylene glycol):
(1) Nicotine is NOT a stimulant per se, its effect on the body/brain depends on the dose - low doses do have a stimulating effect but high doses cause the opposite, extremely high doses can stop your heart...
(2) PG - propylene glycol is NOT proven to cause respiratory infections (HOW COULD IT???) - on the opposite, by U.S. Army conducted research with primates inhaling massive amounts of PG daily for a period of up to 18 mos it was shown to actually decrease the risk of a respirator infection by either viruses or bacteria... and (3), to my knowledge, there was also NO conclusive study being conducted on the effects of "secondhand" vape or "passive" vaping... look it up and don't spread bullshit!

99% of nicotine related vapes do not have ANY COMBUSTION at all! Please do your research more thoroughly before informing the general population, there is already too much misinformation going around these days. Vapes have a metal coil (similar to the coils in the heating unit in your house) to vaporize an oil like substance known as glycerin. "Smoke" as you put it comes from combustion. if you ever get confused again remember the expression most of us grew up with "where there is smoke there is fire." now before you respond with something like dry herb vaporizer comments, this video specifically says that vaporizers dealing directly with nicotine creates smoke.
lastly, please learn a bit more about the science of cigarettes and addiction before using saying nicotine is the addictive substance in cigarettes! studies have conclusively proven nicotine is slightly less addictive than caffeine, while the burning treated tobacco in a SMOKING cigarette creates a chemical reaction resulting in an extremely similar compound to antidepressants. Smokers are addicted to smoking cigarettes not nicotine directly, hence why the nicotine patch and gum have such a low success rate!

Propylene glycol is not as dangerous as you say it is. It does cause very minor irritation in the throat, especially when you start (if it didn't, you wouldn't get any throat hit) but this is very much temporary. It does not cause respiratory infections, but because propylene glycol is a minor irritant, I would advise against people with severe asthma or other underlying severe respiratory problems vaping this and instead using a maximum vegetable glycerine blend.

Also, as most eliquids are mixtures of both propylene glycol and vegetable glycerine, the effects of propylene glycol will be minimal.

The liquid used in these products contain aromas/flavouring, nicotine, glycerin and propylene glycol. Aromas have never been seen as harmful to inhale, even through years of scientific research. Glycerin is ingested by people everyday, through different foods and drinks, and the same goes for propylene glycol. As for how it affects the lungs, propylene glycol is found in asthma inhalators, and has been used for MANY years, and nothing ever happened to the consumers, and please note, these people have asthma, that should logically mean, that they would get immediate side effects, if this chemical was harmful, but obviously, they DONT. It has also been used in hospitals for about 70 years, for ventilation systems, which basically works as an anti-bacterial. Nicotine is poisonous, that is true, but an adult human being needs a very high amount to overdose. How can people still think cigarettes are okay, when tobacco smoke contains harmful carcinogens like methanol, benzene, formaldehyde, arsenic, ammonia, hydrogen cyanide, tar and many other toxic ingredients?!

This video is a little misleading on a few issues here. First, the highest recorded diacetyl levels in Eliquid were 100 times less than is typically found in cigarettes. There have been no recorded cases of popcorn lung in smokers.

Secondly, the increase in teens using Ecigarettes is paired with the decrease in teens smoking traditional cigarettes. Teens are going to do what they're gonna do. I'd much rather they use Ecigarettes, honestly.

Thirdly, there have been studies on the effects of inhalation exposure to propylene glycol since the 1940s. It's non toxic, and the irritation on mucous membranes comes from it being a hydroscopic substance i.e. it absorbs water on the surface of the skin. If you drink plenty of water, you'll be perfectly fine.

There are plenty of longitudinal studies on all the compounds that an Ecigarettes user is exposed to. It's perfectly reasonable to extrapolate long-term risk from this data.

Propylene glycol has been used by the medical community for decades as a common solvent for various drugs and delivery of drugs via inhalation. It doesn't bother people that much or hundreds of thousands of asthmatics, people sick with pneumonia or bronchitis requiring temporary inhaler use, or people with COPD needing inhalers would have yielded a massively obvious pattern of unacceptable side effects by now and removed from widespread medical use. PG is also commonly used in mouthwash; yes, you do absorb it through your mouth's tissues. No, it does not give you cancer. PG is actually a handy solvent (when something other than water or alcohol is desired) for a variety of things and so it is literally in thousands and thousands of commonly used products and has been for decades. PG and its side effects are fairly well know by now, not that mysterious. New studies are being launched only because of the new vape culture and the bullshit fear mongering around it. Please pay more attention to your sources next time.

Misleading people about propylene glycol and making it seem scary and mysterious will only further demonize vapers, and more importantly, prevent smokers from making the switch to a significantly less destructive system of nicotine delivery (because the likelihood of people giving up their nicotine permanently is about that of giving up the other popular stimulant, caffeine). Nicotine itself (not tobacco or tobacco additives) is not the part that kills people, though it of course can kill at extreme doses, and actually improves short term memory (through acetylcholine), fine motor skills and a few other things that make people interested in it as a nootropic (though I am not advocating such a thing), and a few productivity-enhancing things that make people love caffeine. It has similar side effects as caffeine too, so it's not all perfect. I don't recommend nonsmokers to take up nicotine gum or patches or vaping devices for the purpose of using nicotine as a smart drug, because part of nicotine's mechanism, it's interaction with our nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, is what makes it addictive (though not as addictive as a commercial cigarette because of how the cigarette has been tweaked to make it more addictive).

Also, vegetable glycerin is another common base for ejuices since it produces more vapor, and a denser vapor, and because some people have a sensitivity to PG.

One downside (actually, can be an upside too, depending on your intent) to vaping is the vapor itself; the body absorbs nicotine in vapor more slowly than nicotine in smoke, water vapor and base vapor provide a partial but temporary moisture obstacle between the nicotine and your mucosal tissues (the vast majority of nicotine is actually absorbed by the tissues in the sinus cavities and mouth, not the lungs). A drag on a cigarette is felt nearly instantaneously as nicotine is far less impeded by being carried in smoke as opposed to vapor and enters the bloodstream faster, but a drag from an eliquid atomizer comes with a certain lag time before the vaper feels it (it differs on what the VG/PG ratio of the liquid is). This inherently makes ecigs slightly less addictive because it is often perceived as LESS SATISFYING compared to smoke delivery (it's also less addictive for other reasons I mentioned before). It's fairly well known now that speed of delivery intensifies the effects of drugs and makes them more addictive. Vaping typically delivers less nicotine in general due to the popularity of low-nicotine concentrations of eliquid - also because the mg-to-ml concentration of nicotine in an eliquid that would be comparable to the average cigarette (about 18-24 mg/ml give or take) is very harsh and unpalatable to a lot of people, so 12mg, 8mg, 6mg, 3mg or even 0mg are used more often by all except the most hardcore vapers and former heavy smokers. This is one reason why many smokers have a hard time staying with the e-cig after making the switch, and many relapse. Think of methadone and the addicts who relapse despite having regular access to this medication; it's just not as satisfying and many go back to the street drug again. It's not a perfect analogy but it's adequate.

Lastly, there is no reason to be suspicious of eliquid from various companies if you buy your own US Pharmacopeia grade PG or VG and concentrated nicotine solution (in PG or VG or a mix of both),
concentrated flavorings (these are commonly used food grade flavorings usually produced for the production of candy, soda, juices, other drinks, pastry baking, etc, but now there are flavorings being produced that are exclusively intended for vaping, for example they will not have any artificial coloring or other compounds unnecessary for vaping - this both decreases the different compounds in flavorings, better for vapers, and extends the life of atomizers) and make your own damn juice (much cheaper that way too). Close-knit vape communities actually keep vendors honest (nearly always themselves vapers), and as long as they stay small businesses that are in regular contact with their customers and the vape communities there is little to worry about. It's typically the larger companies and corporations who are detached from the human element of their revenue that you have to worry about.





It's actually the little bit of concentrated flavoring in eliquid that can be the mystery for a lot of people (who don't make their own). The nicotine, the PG, the VG, we know enough about these and they've been with us long enough for us to know these are no big deal. It's the unknown stuff that's in artificial flavors (natural flavors too, actually, since most of the time when you see "natural flavoring" on something at the supermarket, chances are it's not a simple extract from a natural source like most people think it is) that we need to study, not just for vapers, but for consumers everywhere. What's a common solvent in food grade flavors, "natural" and artificial? Propylene glycol.

On the whole, I think moderate vaping is not a damaging as standing in a hot shower or steam bath for a while, because you absorb much more chlorine that way (by inhaling tap water vapor, you will absorb more chlorine through your sinus and lung tissues than through your skin alone, though you are still absorbing chlorine through your skin for the duration) and chlorine is definitely not-awesome for us in the concentrations usually put in our water. Of course we drink quite a bit of chlorine in our water, but there's no need to make things worse by inhaling it and soaking in it too. Eliquid vapor is also considerably less harmful than vehicle exhaust and smog ... but nobody seems to be all that up in arms about that, or leaving their homes with masks on their faces (unless you live in China I guess). . So it's really weird to see people make a fuss about eliquid vapor; the reaction is very irrational. People being personally offended by vapor (because face it, it's not usually about fear, it's usually about a sense of entitlement and an opportunity to put someone down and feel good about yourself), provided some douchebag is not literally blowing thick clouds in your face, provided that it's mostly dissipated by the time you can smell the flavor? It's all psychological, it's in their head, because they cannot disassociate it with cigarette smoke (though they easily disassociate it from smog). But since when does the public in general do anything rationally?

Tell people the truth, the whole truth: vaping IS safer/healthier than smoking - but by no means is this better than abstaining from either. Encourage smokers to switch, there's plenty of profit in that, no need to try to recruit new nicotine users. Stop demonizing e-cigarettes.

You could have also included that most of the companies that were found to contain the diacetyl-containing additives moved to self-correct those problems by removing those ingredients from their liquids. Another point that you could have mentioned is that while kids and young adults may be taking up vaping at a higher rate, many of them are purchasing e-liquid that contains no nicotine. E-liquid can be bought in a range of nicotine levels from as high as 32mg per 10mil. bottle to as low as none in most cases. Many former smokers have seemed themselves off of nicotine altogether by slowly lowering the amount of nicotine their e-liquid contains until they are eventually vaping 0 nicotine liquid. That information is something that often goes unreported by the general media.

Propylene glycol doesn't hurt you, trust me I've been vaping every day for 2 years...and that part at the end about variations in e-liquid manufacturers is largely inaccurate.  In the months leading up to the FDA approving vaping as legal, the bulk of "skeptical mainstream media" aka CNN, raised the same concerns, as well as ran slanderous segments about how "dangerous" e-cigarettes are, though all of their evidence was purely circumstantial.  As a result, 99.9% of e-liquid manufacturers aggressively advertised the contents of their products so as to avoid any uncertainty. At that time it was common to use a propylene glycol/vegetable glicerate mix as a base, since propylene glycol provided a "throat hit" or slight harshness when inhaling, that resembled the feeling of a real cigarette, and you could choose to raise or lower that level in your liquid to your preference...but it soon became obvious that this type of mixture was only really preferred by people who were just quitting cigarettes and making the switch to vaping.  As of today, almost all e-liquid is made exclusively with a vegetable glicerate base, completely eliminating the use of the questionable propylene glycol....So stop smoking cigarettes and make the switch if you haven't already...you'll be AMAZED at how much better food tastes, as well as an increase of your sense of smell...and no more coughing, shortness of breath...I could go on and on... :)

On such subjects, which are complex and covered by misinformation, you should take more time to read and weight [real] studies, compare figures with real life risks evaluations (like air studies, workers exposition limits, etc.). You make, in this video, a lot of simplifications at a point it's simply often wrong.
To highlight some :
- Nicotine is not the [only] thing that makes smoking addictive and certainly not the cause of cravings (hint, google IMAO). Most vapers, after 9-18 weeks without tobacco feel the (huge) difference.
- Nicotine effect on heart rate is more complex (as it also decreases stress and lowers the heart rate/blood flow, especially without associated monoxyde intake).
- Smoking has always been dangerous because of monoxyde inhalation which was known to be dangerous before the last century. Effect of simple chemicals in the long term have been studied for years which was not the state of the science in the 50's and vapor is quite simple compared to the thousands chemical in tobacco smoke.
- The current knowledge of long term risks associated with PG/VG/water/nicotine (decades of studies, billions of people exposed during their whole life) can give quite precise risk evaluations for what constitues 90+% of eLiquids.
- Effect on bystanders have been proven to be without risks for years (hint, look at figures and compare to indoor air studies for example).
Hope it'll help you make better videos on this subject. Feel free to ask for links to complete your research.

While I agree with you on one thing, that ejuice needs to be better regulated, there's a few things that need to be said since the misinformation in this video is a bit crazy. First of all, that is an e-cig, NOT a vape. There is a difference. An e-cig is a device that is meant to mimic a cigarette and uses cartridges. It's not reloadable with different juices, once it's done you toss it. Vapes however have replaceable coils, generally don't mimic a cigarette (particularly with mechs and box mods, but even vape pens look nothing like them) and have a tank with which you can fill, refill, and refill again with juice. E-cigs are classified as vaporizers, but that doesn't make it a vape. A vape is a specific term for the good kind of vaporizer. The other major difference is e-cigs generally use crap like sweeteners and such, while most Juice companies are moving towards natural flavoring because they know regulations are going to come out eventually and they want to be on top of the game before it happens, lest they have to be shut down until they get up to code. Not to mention the whole point of moving to vaping is to be more healthy than cigarettes, so why put crap into it? I know my vape shop ONLY buys from people who use natural flavorings, so I can guarantee what I put into my lungs isn't going to harm me. You can taste chemicals and it burns, it's not a pleasant thing, so most companies won't even use stuff like food coloring because it sucks and people won't buy it.

Another thing is your mention of Propylene Glycol. Now, what you said wasn't entirely incorrect, although you missed several uses for it and it almost makes me wonder why it wasn't mentioned since these are very big medical uses. Nebulizers, for example. Not to mention inhalers. If it was bad to have in your lungs, do you honestly think they'd allow it to be used as medicine for lung disease? No, of course not. That would be like giving someone with a peanut allergy small doses of peanuts to cure it. Propylene Glycol is perfectly safe to inhale.

The study you talk about where you say "propelyne glycol is know to be a lung irritant and cause infections" is bogus
To Quote realclearscience.com 
" there's a "little" problem with the study that escaped the scrutiny of early reporting. Mice have vastly higher rates of cotinine metabolism than humans. While the half-life of cotinine in mice is roughly 35 to 50 minutes, the half-life of cotinine in humans is approximately 20 hours! This massive disparity means that mice have to be exposed to much higher amounts of e-cigarette vapor at faster rates in order to reach comparable cotinine levels to humans." 


"As Mukhin and Rose further explained (emphasis mine):"It should be noted that in our calculations we postulated that the blood for cotinine measurement was taken immediately after the end of 90 min of exposure. In the results section the authors stated that “Blood was collected … within 1 h of the final exposure” but in the methods section they stated that “exposure was assessed by measuring serum cotinine at 1 h after exposure.” If the last statement is correct, because of the fast elimination of cotinine in mice the level of exposure in the study was 3 times higher (2^(60/37.5) ≈ 3) than the above-calculated values. In other words, to obtain the same exposure in humans the e-cig user should take 11000 – 13000 puffs per day. Assuming 8 hours of sleep per day, in order to acquire such a high number of puffs e-cig users would need to take 11-13 puffs per minute and thus practically take an e-cig puff with each breath."

Every video on Youtube has something positive and negative to say about vaping vs. smoking, and in every video, it contradicts the others. So going to a Youtube video to learn about vaping vs. smoking is like going to a homeless shelter to get financial advice. In 100 videos, vaping causes cancer, and in another 100 videos, vaping can't cause cancer. You wanna know the truth? Nothing can cause cancer short of radiation. Cancer is a mutation of the cells that is happening in your body regardless if you smoke or drink. Hell, your body creates and destroys at least one cancer cell a day. However, there is some truth to the whole cancer subject when it comes to smoking and drinking. Because nicotine is a stimulant, it can accelerate the growth of cancer when it becomes present in the body. So, smokers are indeed more at risk of dying from cancer, but to be fair, they already had it in the first place. 

Of course the problem is you have people that are biased towards one or the other, and ASAPscience so far is the only one that remained relatively unbiased towards either. No one is saying they are good for you, but if you must smoke (like myself) vaping is clearly the better way to go.

I believe this video is biased and a bit ignorant towards vaping. If you really want to tell people what science says about it, look it up. A study was done not too long ago about if the vapor is harmful or not. Scientific studies said that inhaling the vapor is no more dangerous than inhaling the air we breathe. Also many or most e-liquids are not pure propylene glycol. On the market now, you probably won't find any e-liquids that are 100% propylene glycol, you will find that it is mixed with vegetable glycerin(which you didn't mention). Most common in at 70%VG 30%PG - 80%VG 20%PG - 90%VG 10%PG - and sometimes 100%VG. Propylene glycol is mostly used as a carrier for the nicotine and or flavoring. Also, almost every e-liquid company that i know(which is a ton) does not contain diacetyl in their e-liquids. I have been vaping for a long time after quitting smoking, and i can honestly say that i've never felt better. Also, instead of trying to give vaping a bad name, and saying that 6% - 20% of younger people find it appealing and try it, why don't you list the decrease in percentage of younger people trying cigarettes?? And vaping has been around for quite some time, as far back as 8+ years. I'm sure if it was harmful, someone would know by now. And for some reason, people always tend to associate marijuana with vaping, when it is completely different. And the thing that bothers me the most, is that propylene glycol is definitely NOT a lung irritant, as it is used in inhalers.... Some people are affected by it because of a slight allergy to propylene glycol. My sister tried it and got a headache and had an allergy to it, so she tried a Max VG e-liquid and everything was fine.  Stop the ignorance towards vaping, do your research, and don't make  biased videos.

looked up Propylene glycol, for those of you interested in the irritation and infection part that wasn't well talked on: (From Wikipedia)

Prolonged contact with propylene glycol is essentially non-irritating to the skin.[30] Undiluted propylene glycol is minimally irritating to the eye, producing slight transient conjunctivitis; the eye recovers after the exposure is removed. Exposure to mists may cause eye irritation, as well as upper respiratory tract irritation. Inhalation of propylene glycol vapors appears to present no significant hazard in ordinary applications.[31] However, limited human experience indicates that inhalation of propylene glycol mists could be irritating to some individuals.[32] It is therefore recommended that propylene glycol not be used in applications where inhalation exposure or human eye contact with the spray mists of these materials is likely, such as simulated fogs for theatrical productions, or antifreeze solutions for emergency eye wash stations.[33]
Propylene glycol does not cause sensitization, and it shows no evidence of being a carcinogen or of being genotoxic

There may be some negative effects of vaping, that being said, I vape often and have never experienced any irritation or infection of any kind; nor has anyone I know (some of whom have been vaping for around 10 years). Don't jump to conclusions on wheter or not it is bad for you. As an avid vaper I will always be keeping my eyes on reliable studies about the health risks.

Glycerine tends to be the most prevalent substance in e-cigarette liquid, which was not even mentioned in this video.  It is much less irratating than propylene glycol nor does it metabolize into anything potentially harmful.

That being said, the main danger of regular cigarettes is tar accumulation in the lungs, which contains poly-cyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, the main cancer causing substances produced by combustion. There are plenty others, but this is these are mainly the "tarry" substances that make up the accumulated glob. Not to mention the harm the tar itself does as a physical entity by accumulating in the lungs. I don't believe for one second that no one ever considered that cigarettes weren't harmful, before the long-term scientific observations. You're inhaling shit that has been lit on fire; does tar seem appetizing? No, it seems pretty intuitively poisonous.

Something being "safe" is a matter of philosophical discussion, and is also quite subjective. Therefore, in my opinion, e-cigarettes eliminate the main health concerns of smoking regular cigarettes, and it can be said with certainty that they are safer by comparison. That is, of course, it's found 15 years from now that people are dying from vaping for some reason that I couldn't possibly predict.

I think, as I was saying before, that before we knew regular cigarettes were causing cancer and all the other ailments its known for, there were probably people saying, "hmm.. that can't be good for you".  I think the primary reason vaping (and second-hand vaping) has come into question is due to the fact that smoking, in general, has quite a stigma surrounding it, and people are biased to think that inhaling any vapor besides air is potentially harmful.  We inhale plenty of nasty shit just breathing normally, that's for sure.

There's a few misconceptions in the video, intended or not. For instance, the idea that Nicotine takes only about 6 seconds to get to the brain and start soothing cravings. This may be true of traditional cigarettes, but with vaporizers, the liquid droplets are too large to be efficiently absorbed by the lung. Nicotine absorption typically happens in the mucous membranes of the mouth or throat - which can delay nicotine spikes in the blood for up to 20 minutes. This is a big cause of dual-use, especially in new vapers who are using it to get away (or cut down) on traditional cigarettes.

Secondly, the concept of temperature control in vaporizers is a rather new development and hasn't been widely adopted yet. While there is a general range of temperature these devices operate at, letting the wick get dry prevents the coil from cooling efficiently and can spike temperatures up to a point where the liquid and wicking can undergo thermal breakdown - causing the release of formaldehyde, hence the infamous studies which found 4x the level of formaldehyde in vapes than in traditional cigarettes. Looking at their methodology, it's clear that they were letting the wicks get dry and still putting power to the coils long after a normal user would have stopped. This is what vapers call a "dry hit", and it's horrible taste and harshness generally prevents further use until the issue is corrected.

Temperature control devices exist now, and use different coil materials which increase resistance as they heat up. By measuring the resistance over time, it's possible to get a fairly accurate estimate on coil temperature. So your coil will always stay at the temperature you set it (218c or 425f for me), because the power to the coil automatically fluctuates to prevent it from going over that set temperature. When your wick runs dry, the resistance (and heat) of the coil will shoot up extremely fast, triggering a safety mechanism which prevents the device from firing altogether. So you never get that "dry hit".

On the downside, the most common material to use in temperature control devices are Ni200 (Nickel) wire, which has some safety concerns of it's own. Titanium wire is becoming slowly more popular, but it's still on the fringes, and is not totally without it's own safety concerns. Albeit, the temperatures needed to produce Ti02 in quantity are far above what most of these devices are capable of producing under temperature control. (My device maxes at 300c, whereas it takes between 600-800c to produce Ti02). Though it is possible to produce them if using Titanium Wire on non-temp controlled devices. Kanthal, as imperfect as it may be, remains the best choice for most vaping devices.

And while it's true that vaping has seen a rise in popularity among young people, it's also been accompanied by a corresponding continual decline in traditional tobacco use. While vaping isn't "safe", it's a significant harm reduction over tobacco, and the modularity of nicotine in the juice (from 3.6mg/ml down to 0.2mg/ml - and even nicotine free), means that they have a much easier avenue of stepping down and quitting if they do get addicted. Cigarettes only come in ONE nicotine level, high, and it's either that or total abstinence (cold turkey) if you want to quit. The issue of regulation is a bit sticky in the vape community, but there is one in which nearly everybody on both sides of the debate agree needs to be put in place. Total sales restrictions on customers under the age of 18. It certainly won't stop kids from picking up vaping, just as it hasn't stopped them smoking traditional cigarettes, but it'll help and it needs to be in place.

Lastly, just a short word on diacetyl. The video is right to identify flavorings as, presently, the major source of concern when talking about the unknowns of vaping. This is something the community has done a fairly good job about combating, at least when a unreasonable risk is presented - such as diacetyl. Most juice companies will not use this flavoring (and the few who have, and continue to do so, have been publicly shamed by the community - such as SuicideBunny). Some other companies have used other diketones which approximate the same flavor, but unfortunately have shown to have the same (or worse) capacity to cause the same tissue damage. For the time being, I'd say it's best to avoid all custard/butter/creamy flavors. Unfortunately, it's not always the e-juice manufacturer's fault. Selling flavorings for the purpose of inhalation is new to most flavor manufacturers (who are used to just selling it as a food additive), and often flavorings sold to e-juice manufacturers that has been labeled as diacetyl free - isn't. I think that if flavoring manufactures wish to continue selling their products to e-cigarette companies, that they should shoulder some of the cost of testing.

Very nice video! A few points I feel that should be made though:

Diacetyl is absolutely a dangerous chemical, but after it's discovery in e-liquid, it has been removed from almost all liquids. It's found in buttery flavorings, so juice manufacturers have almost all switched to alternatives for this chemical.

The other problems faced right now are those of other chemicals, such as acetyl prioponyl and acetoin. These chemicals aren't immediately dangerous, but studies show that they can metabolize into potentially harmful chemicals such as diacetyl in certain conditions.

As far as propylene glycol, it's found to be safe for human consumption and respiration, as it's used in hospital vents and asthma inhalers, but the concern is that of how it reacts to the heat of e-cigs. 

Vegetable glycerine is the other base of e-liquid, which we're also unsure of how it reacts to the heat. 

Then there's the problem of the cotton. E-cigs use kanthal, nichrome, or in some cases nickel or titanium wire and have a battery that pass current through the wire, heating it and vaporizing the liquid off cotton. If the cotton gets too dry, it can burn, and in scenarios like this it's been found that formaldehyde is present, but otherwise it is not.

You should look into some of the alternatives to vaping fluids and other factors. The overlooked aspect of vaping is how it affects people who genuinely wish to quit smoking. My wife was roughly a pack a day smoker. She tried the gum, patches, everything. None of it worked. She'd be back to smoking within a month. Then she tried vaping. Within a week she threw her cigarettes away. After a year she had reduced the nicotine content of her e-juice to 0%. A year after that she stopped vaping as well. This is what is known as progress.

As for children smoking and vaping? That is a societal problem, not a product problem. Without proper guidance from the adults in their lives children will make uneducated and often foolish decisions. Educate, show all sides of a story, and make sure the young have enough information to make an informed decision. They'll more than likely still make foolish decisions, that's part of being young, but at least they'll know better.

Education is the answer. Videos which demonize a product without addressing the positive values as well as the negatives lead to reactionary behavior. I've come across two types of vaping videos on the web. Type A demonizes vaping by presenting facts and giving them bias toward the evils of the product. Type B tends to be avid vapers who are tenaciously defending their habit. I'd like to see a third type which focuses on ways of using the product responsibly. The risks as well as the benefits.

It is true that vaping has its potential risks and needs further study. These risks however are far less potent than smoking. If someone is using it as a gateway to escape a smoking habit, why demonize the act and give it a social stigma?

Everyone making comments about "Oh, well just don't smoke either of them." You are completely correct. It is entirely more healthy for someone to not smoke at all.
BUT if someone DOES smoke for whatever reason, this does not give you the right to judge them (unless there are circumstances such as they are arrogant about it/do not respect you if you don't want to be around secondhand smoke/blow smoke in people's faces/etc., but I have noticed such actions to be rare). Smoking, yes, is not a good life choice, but please don't confuse the choice to smoke with being a personality trait, because it is not. It does not define a person. Of course you can try to get your friend/loved one/whoever to quit smoking, but do not be a douche to them or think badly of them, unless they do this to you, which has nothing to do with smoking and they are just a douche.
tl;dr just because someone smokes does not automatically make them a bad person or a douchebag and please respect this

I was a smoker for 12 years before I started vaping. I switched easily and haven't had to smoke since. Anyone who is addicted to Nicotine should understand how huge that is. My lung capacity is full again, I can walk much farther without being winded, I don't stink, no stained fingers and teeth. All that alone makes the switch worth it to me.

While considering the ramifications of vaping I did a lot of research, read many papers and watched a bunch of videos. Here's what I found. Most academics and doctors agree that vaping is less harmful than smoking, (some citing up to 200 times less harmful) but the clear healthier path is quitting altogether.

It's important to note that nicotine itself isn't actually that bad for you. It's a stimulant similar to caffeine, but it is highly addictive. If you're a smoker I highly recommend giving vaping a try. There are tobacco flavoured e-juices that taste very similar to most brands of cigarettes and help make the transition easier.

The fact that smoke and vapor are completely different was not explained.....

One note from someone who stopped smoking and started vaping. The nicotine is NOT absorbed as quickly using an E-cigarette as it is using a regular cigarette.
It can take several minutes before you notice any effect from vaping and in that time you can end up vaping too much and feel sick for up to an hour.

Another point i want to make is that those young people who started smoking E-cigarettes which marked a rise of 20% in the statistics is actually quite a low number. If there were only 1,000 youths vaping three years ago that means only 200 more youths have started vaping in the past three years. Of course the figures are different but put that into perspective.
Then consider that out of those 200 new vapers, a great deal of them used to smoke or would have smoked cigarettes instead.

And yes, vaping seriously messes with your lungs if you inhale the vapor. Ideally you should only vape with your mouth and not let the vapor get to your lungs. The same way you ideally smoke a cigar.
The problem for smokers of cigarettes who make the transition to vaping is that they will naturally try to inhale to the lungs. And the first 2-3 weeks of vaping is riddled with coughing and wheezing. That stops after a while and assuming you have been cigarette free for 2-3 months and you have another cigarette (which tastes like SHIT by the way) you will cough and feel a nasty burn in your throat and lungs.
Basically, your lungs adjust to vaping and build up a resistance to the irritant.
But if you smoke a regular cigarette after vaping it feels like death is entering your lungs.

Beyond that, there's thousands of different vaping products out on the market. Some are not that good while others give you the best experience you've ever had.

All in all, i still favor vaping over cigarettes any day and have done so for 1.5 years now. Even though i really should stop inhaling to the lungs!

E-cigarettes and vapes are actually different things. E-cigs use that E-liquid from big manufacturers, and are like the gas-station cigar equivalent. Vapes often use fluids too, however these aren't big brand name fluids and are commonly made in-house at vape hobby shops by enthusiasts and shop owners with ingredients public knowledge. It's also my understanding that vape fluid as opposed to E-liquid dose not have a base since they aren't made with the intention of sitting in a warehouse/on shelves for months at a time. Just water, flavoring, and nicotine. As a matter of fact nicotine content varies in vape fluids. Usually High-Medium-low-and even none. Nicotine free and low fluids are actually the most popular, with medium being utilized most often by past smokers, and high nicotine fluid generally being used by smokers in the process of quitting.

Not all of this may be accurate, as this is mostly from memory, however I recommend checking out reddit's Vaping, and E-cigarette subreddits.

In closing, although it may be true that our knowledge on the dangers of smoking come from long term studies, and vaping, the young hobby it is, subject to change as we learn more over the years, It is still a healthier alternative to smoking. It has allowed many smokers an easier path to a safer life. And again big brand name E-fluid is very different from hobbyist made liquids.

Propylene Glycol is used in oxygen tents and asthma inhalers, it is universally known as safe for inhalation by the medical community, which is why they use it on people with damaged or sensitive lungs.

Studies have shown nicotine has NOTHING to do with cigarette addiction and that ecigs are equally as effective whether they contain nicotine or not. Studies have also shown medical benefits to nicotine for conditions like ADHD, bipolar, low blood pressure, migraine headaches, schizophrenia, etc.

Studies performed in the US, UK and Australia showed there has never been a case of ecigs leading anyone, including kids, to smoking.

The potential harm of unknown substances being used in eliquids is the fault of governments banning, restricting or ignoring ecigs rather than embracing and regulating them.

An open letter by over 50 scientists from 15 countries was sent to the WHO telling them to stop bashing ecigs because banning of, and spreading disinformation about, ecigs will result in the needless deaths of millions.

Studies all over the world have found ecigs to be BY FAR more effective in long term quitting of tobacco than ANY other alternative.
