I'm glad that you guys have pointed out that vaporizers have far less adverse effects due to the removal of smoke but your facts are messed up on several points here.

1. Nicotine is not addictive (At least not to the extent that people think it is). Nicotine has mild addictive effects similar to that of caffeine. The addictive parts of smoking are the MAOH inhibitors that are part of the tobacco plant which get into the blood stream (Which are not present in the e-liquids due to the fact that only liquid nicotine is present.). Nicotine is a mild reinforcement agent which had an evolutionary purpose of ensuring that insects who survived eating the tobacco plant would remember they had a bad time and not come back again.

 2. Propylene Glycol is a common additive in MANY different things. Food, antifreeze, medicine. In medicine Propylene Glycal (Here on referred to as PG) is used as a drug solubilizers (It gives the medicine a way to actually get into your blood stream once ingested, inhaled, or applied to your body.). It has shown to have some adverse effects on children, and can cause thrombophelitis. Rapid infusions of high-PG containing drugs have been shown to have adverse effects. Overall, PG is a safe substance otherwise it wouldn't be present in so many things some caution needs to be applied as with any substance. (Source: http://www.drugs.com/inactive/propylene-glycol-270.html )

3. A lot of the companies that put harmful ingredients in their e-liquids are (Surprise surprise) tobacco companies. Tobacco companies are not involved in the vaping industry (Only really selling any products in gas stations) they have not invested a whole lot of money into researching vaping products, and in fact have been actively fighting it (Because they would go bankrupt otherwise.). Most e-liquids only contain a few base ingredients (Nicotine (Optional), PG (To some extent), Vegetable Glycerine (For vapor effect. PG is not visible ;P), Flavoring (Optional.) While some of the flavorings can cause issues, not all of them do this and again studies have shown the more harmful ingredients are mainly used by the tobacco companies. (A common theory is part of the reason is so that people can point and say LOOK HARMFUL INGREDIENTS! But ignoring theories and focusing on the facts Tobacco Companies have been actively fighting vaping, and do not have that much stock in the industry.).

4. The 'ultrafine particles' released by vaporizers produce no real harmful effects in people around the person vaping. Any particles produced by that are well below the legal safety limit (The harmful substances exhaled being similar to those normally exhaled by humans only a difference of 20-30 particles per million has been shown. Ie. Not statistically significant.) Nicotine released by vaping is not harmful to those around you because, refer to point 1. Nicotine is not harmful.

The reason the only links I have is for PG is because the rest of my knowledge comes from a myriad of studies and other sources. I've looked at a lot of positive and negative studies, looked at their biases, tried to find out any flaws in methodology and concluded from the short term studies that have been done that vaping most likely is a safe alternative to smoking, and probably overall a safe practice if handled responsibly.
Yes you will need to do some personal research and ensure you aren't actually vaping harmful substances until the freak-out session around vaping calms down and more research is done by the FDA to help further regulate the industry. But overall it IS a safer alternative for those attempting to quit smoking (With studies showing that it has the highest success rate, with participants even quitting vaping afterwards.) which is at least a positive thing right?

This video missed one important thing: nicotine and THC are neurotoxins. Decades of neurobiological research has concluded that nicotine has potent neurodegenerative effects, and new research overwhelmingly suggests that THC damages the hippocampus and the temporal lobes. The neurobiological effects of nicotine and THC should be stressed, because people seem to be duped into believing that the only reason smoking is unhealthy is because of the effects on the lungs - in reality, vapes merely deliver the neurotoxic compounds via a different medium, in a much more concentrated manner.

The biggest problem with e-cigs right now is highlighted in this video, although only briefly: Regulation.

Fact of the matter is, most e-cigs use e-liquid or e-juice, and a lot of people have taken to making their own juices. With no federal regulations, you generally don't have a definite idea of what goes into an e-juice unless you make it yourself. Most people selling that stuff are professional enough to avoid poisoning people, as far as I'm aware. But even so, with no regulations, there's a risk.

That said, e-cigs use the same kind of technology as smoke machines: You know, the things that get used all the time at parties, music festivals, clubs, stage productions and countless other places. E-cigs haven't been used for long enough to study their effects properly. But smoke machines are old news. We've been using those for decades, and if my research is correct, there's never been any health complications linked to long-term exposure to them (as might occur with set crew on stage productions and concerts, fr'instance.)

The act of vapor inhalation itself generally isn't considered a problem. The problems start arising when random people mix up chemicals and sell them to other random people to inhale as vapor. I doubt we can ever get conclusive studies on vaping (which I think is a stupid bloody term, but there you go) until there's a federal regulation on what is and is not okay to put into juices.
